clinical_study.brief_title: Lag of Accommodation Involving Young Myopes and Patterned Spectacle Lenses
clinical_study.official_title: Lag of Accommodation Involving Young Myopes and Patterned Spectacle Lenses

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the study is to measure the difference in the lag of accommodation of two iterations of patterned spectacle lenses compared to a control spectacle. The Pattern 1 iteration induces less reduction in contrast than Pattern 2.

primary_outcome.description: 1) Autorefractor best vision sphere measured at distance and at 40cm with each pair of treatment spectacles

clinical_study.condition: Myopia, Myopia Progression, Lag of Accommodation, Hyperopic Retinal Blur, Reduction in Contrast

criteria.textblock:
A person is eligible for inclusion in the study if he/she:
1. Age 6-18 years of age, with a maximum of 6 of the first 25 completed participants being older than 14 years of age.
2. Is able to read (or be read to), understand and sign the assent document if under 17 years old or is able to read, understand and sign the consent document if aged 17 or 18 years.
3. Is under 17 years old and is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian who is able to read, understand and sign the parental information and permission document.
4. Currently wearing spectacles, contact lenses to correct myopia or is wearing no correction due to low prescription.
5. Should be myopic by non-cycloplegic auto-refraction.
6. Should have minus power in both principal meridians in non-cycloplegia auto-refraction.
7. For non-CL wearers, SER by auto-refraction should be between -0.25 DS and -0.75 DS in both eyes (sphere power no less than -0.25 DS and cylindrical power no more than -1.00 DC).
8. For CL wearers, over-refraction SER by auto-refraction not greater than -0.75 DS in either eye;
9. Is willing and able to follow instructions.
A person will be excluded from the study if he/she:
1. Is participating in any concurrent clinical or research study.
2. Is currently not wearing and has no history of wearing a correction for myopia control.
3. Has amblyopia in either eye or known to have any other binocular vision disorder, such as accommodative insufficiency.
4. Has any known active ocular disease and/or infection.
5. Has a systemic condition that in the opinion of the investigator may affect a study outcome variable. Examples include diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism.
6. Is using any systemic or topical medications that in the opinion of the investigator may affect a study outcome variable. Examples include Atropine eye drops.
7. Has undergone strabismus surgery, refractive error surgery or intraocular surgery.
8. Is a child of a member of the study team.
